Jean Valjean.Action: Endures harsh physical conditions (waist-deep in water, chained, in storm) without showing any sign of weakness or complaint, indicating strong resilience and mental fortitude.
Remains silent and emotionally unaffected (seems to feel nothing) amidst brutal treatment, potentially indicating controlled composure and self-discipline.
Defies Javert by staring back and then shows great physical strength to haul the mast ashore, demonstrating resilience rather than submission.
Explains to Javert that he stole a loaf of bread to save his sister's starving child, expressing a self-sacrificing and compassionate motivation.
Defies Javert by staring him down and then deliberately displays strength by throwing the mast ashore.
Understands his situation and recognizes the meaning of his parole and the law's oppression.
Walks away from the prison, hardly able to take in that he is free, showing internal struggle and hope for a new life.
Offers to work by asking overseer for a day's work, showing willingness to engage honestly and be part of society.
Remains silent and compliant during overseer's inspection, quietly takes off hat revealing scars.
Walks into town and enters an inn showing hunger but does not confront or complain despite wary treatment.
Successfully navigates inspection by overseer and officer, obtains passport with proper authorization and leaves without trouble.
Maintains low profile and discretion in the inn despite suspicion arising from visible scars and documents, avoiding confrontation.
Threatens children with stick when they throw stones at him.
Looks longingly at a family scene through a window, showing his deep yearning for love and belonging.
Attempts to find shelter by asking the innkeeper and jailer for lodging despite being refused.
Does not give up after repeated refusals and instead finds an alternative place to rest by stooping through a low doorway and lying down on straw despite the danger.
Threatens children throwing stones at him to make them scatter, successfully defending himself.
Fails to secure proper shelter for the night and ends up sleeping in a dangerous area where he is attacked by a dog, resulting in injury.
Collapses exhausted and suspiciously accepts the Bishop's offer of food and shelter.
Collapses exhausted and hungry, moves slowly, wary and suspicious when approached.
Despite his fear and suspicion, accepts the Bishop's invitation and follows him into the house.
Laughs a strange laugh when the Bishop offers him a bed despite his criminal past.
Fears judgment and respects the Bishop's trust by not immediately stealing the silver despite having the opportunity.
Considers stealing the Bishop's silver in the middle of the night.
Reflects deeply on his past crimes and suffering while acknowledging the Bishop's kindness and trust, feeling shame and a growing awareness of his soul.
Reflects deeply on his past actions and the new chance given to him by the Bishop, showing self-awareness and internal struggle.
Is initially bewildered and passive after receiving the silver candlesticks, indicating some hesitation or lack of confidence in what to do next.
Examines the yellow passport with solemnity and raises it as if to an altar, indicating reverence and inner conflict.
Reflects on his shame and sin, showing self-awareness and remorse.
Symbolically tears up the yellow passport and discards it over a valley, signifying rejection of his past identity.
Plans to escape from 'the world of Jean Valjean,' signaling a desire for transformational change, possibly to better himself.
Instructs Foreman to handle the factory conflict patiently instead of intervening harshly or immediately.
Upon seeing Javert, instructs the foreman calmly to deal with the escalating conflict among the factory women and Fantine, showing confidence and delegation ability.
Does not directly intervene immediately in the conflict on the factory floor, instead relies on foreman to handle the situation.
Hears Fantine's pitiful cry for help but does not immediately intervene, focusing instead on Javert and other concerns.
Welcomes Javert politely and respectfully upon his arrival at the factory.
Hears Fantine's pitiful cry for help but chooses to focus on other concerns instead of intervening immediately.
Calmly welcomes Javert and agrees to cooperate with the law enforcement, demonstrating controlled and confident behavior.
Rushes to help lift the overturned cart off the trapped worker, risking his own safety.
Gives a sharp, somewhat guarded glance to Javert on recognition.
Identifies a strategic way to lift the cart by bracing himself under the harder ground side to save Fauchelevent.
Throws a sharp glance at Javert, signaling awareness and confidence.
Warns others to get back due to the risk of the cart falling, showing situational awareness.
Strains every muscle to lift a heavy cart and save Fauchelevent from being crushed
Offers immediate physical help to Fauchelevent after rescuing him
Firmly tells Fauchelevent 'No more cart driving for you!'
Challenges Javert to speak openly despite tension
Strains every muscle and skillfully lifts a heavy cart to save Fauchelevent, demonstrating physical strength, determination, and presence of mind.
Holds Javert's gaze and challenges him to speak, showing confidence and control in a tense situation.
Quickly assists the injured Fauchelevent after the rescue, taking appropriate action to help others.
Talks kindly to a beggar and gives him some money.
Talks to a beggar and gives some money before moving on
Intervenes to stop Fantine's arrest, insists she needs a doctor not jail, shows compassion towards her plight.
Steps out from the shadows confidently to intervene on behalf of Fantine, contradicting Javert's authority to protect her and insisting she be spared jail and given a doctor.
Holds Fantine's hands, sincerely asks how to help her, and commits to taking her to the hospital and rescuing her daughter Cosette.
Immediately recognizes Fantine's suffering, offers help, and takes her to the hospital without hesitation.
Shows emotional insight and decisiveness in accepting responsibility to save Fantine's daughter Cosette.
Conceals his shock upon learning Javert's mistake but treats Javert with understanding and states it's a minor sin, encourages him to return to his post.
Raises a commanding hand to insist Javert obey him and stop protesting.
Maintains composure and conceals shock upon learning Javert was mistaken, showing emotional self-control.
Calmly and confidently handles Javert’s confession, directing him to return to his post and accept responsibility.
Takes command of the situation by raising a hand to end further argument, demonstrating leadership and decisiveness.
Paces the office, deeply disturbed, showing some internal turmoil but no clear negative effect on decision-making in the scene.
Contemplates saving the innocent man in his place despite the risk to himself.
Worries about abandoning his workers who depend on him.
Reflects on the pain of condemning an innocent man who resembles him.
Hesitates and struggles internally to decide whether to lie to protect himself.
Confesses his true identity in court to exonerate an innocent man, risking his own safety and reputation.
Shows concern for Fantine by immediately asking after her daughter and reacting with anger towards the inadequate support sent.
Kneels by Fantine's bedside, offers comfort and reassurance, promises to protect Cosette, physically warms Fantine in her last moments.
Pledges to care for Fantine's suffering child and asks for time to do so before surrendering to Javert.
Confronts Javert peacefully, emphasizing his duty and compassion rather than escaping.
Swears to raise Fantine's child and care for her despite danger.
Defies Javert and asserts his strength and determination to survive.
Calls Javert 'scum' and equates himself with the gutter-born.
Promises to protect Cosette and gives Thenardiers a significant sum of money without haggling or resentment.
Acknowledges Thenardier's feelings politely but maintains dignity while completing the transaction.
Does not engage with Thenardiers' insinuations or suspicions, simply completes the payment.
Firmly commits to protecting Cosette and pays Thenardiers a large sum without hesitation to secure her safety.
Responds calmly and confidently to Thenardiers' attempts to negotiate, ending the discussion decisively.
Assures Cosette he will be like a father and mother to her, showing sincere care and protectiveness.
Leads Cosette out of the inn and lifts her into the waiting cab, ensuring her safety and taking decisive action to protect her.
Responds affirmatively and confidently to Cosette's question about being like a father to her, showing emotional assurance and resolve.
Places arm around Cosette to protect her from the jolting of the cab, watches her sleep, brushes hair from her face, ensures she is comfortable.
Expresses deep love, trust, and fear of failing Cosette, acknowledges the gift of life and love she brought him.
Avoids official checkpoint by slipping away from gate and climbing over a wall to protect Cosette.
Carefully protects Cosette during a bumpy carriage ride, ensuring her comfort and safety.
Observes soldiers checking documents at a city gate, then chooses to avoid detection by slipping out of the carriage and escaping along a wall, rather than attempting to pass through the checkpoint.
Climbs over a broken wall and navigates through dark slum streets and narrow paths to elude pursuers and ensure Cosette's safety.
Ties a rope around Cosette to help her escape a dead end by climbing a high wall, ensuring her safety before escaping himself.
Cautiously holds Cosette still and quiet until Javert leaves, showing situational awareness and care.
Observes surroundings carefully, listens to chanting, and investigates the building.
Recognizes and reconnects with Fauchelevent, recalling past assistance and leveraging the connection.
Directly asks for help and accepts sanctuary in a convent to protect Cosette, showing strategic problem-solving.
Giving alms to beggars as they walk back from evening church service.
Instinctively puts his arm around Cosette, guarding her jealously from Marius's distant gaze.
Protects Cosette by putting his arm around her, guarding her from a potential threat.
Gives alms to beggars after church service, demonstrating generosity but possibly putting himself in a vulnerable position.
Approaches the Thenardiers' alley despite their suspicious presence, potentially walking into a trap.
Denies the false accusation from Thenardier calmly, refuses to engage in violence despite threat from gang.
Averts his face to avoid recognition by Javert despite risk, probably protecting others.
Maintains composure and denies the false accusation from Thenardier calmly.
Avoids recognition by a vigilant Javert by averting his face.
Leaves the scene quickly and quietly, escaping the hostile gang and Javert.
Knocks and opens Cosette's door, closes her shutters to comfort her.
Speaks tenderly to Cosette, acknowledges her loneliness and wishes to fill her passing hours.
Refuses to discuss his past, saying some words are better unheard and unsaid.
Lives simply and gives the best room to Cosette, showing selflessness and care.
Knocks and opens Cosette's door, closes her shutters to provide comfort and protection.
Responds gently and tenderly to Cosette's sadness, showing emotional intelligence.
Refuses to speak about his past, stating some words are better unheard and unsaid.
Lives simply and modestly, giving the best room to Cosette rather than himself.
Gives the best room in his simple home to Cosette.
Sits with his back to Cosette before speaking about truth being given by God.
Walks down the garden path to the gate and peers into the shadows, sensing something unusual.
Shows pensive behavior, thoughtfully considering the situation after sensing Cosette may have been talking to someone.
Returns inside without confronting Marius or investigating further immediately.
Rushing to Cosette's room to protect her after hearing a scream and angry voices outside.
Holding Cosette in his arms and showing concern for her safety.
Deciding to flee with Cosette to protect her from danger.
Hears a scream, quickly assesses the threat, and decides to take immediate protective action by preparing to flee with Cosette.
Interprets the scream and shadowy figures as a sign that Javert has discovered his identity and cover, showing insight and awareness.
Decides to leave immediately to protect Cosette, demonstrating decisiveness and foresight.
Insists on leaving immediately despite Cosette's protests and distress, commanding her to hurry and prepare to leave without addressing her fears.
Decides quickly to leave with Cosette and prepares to act immediately to ensure their safety.
Urges Cosette to hurry without engaging in prolonged discussion, showing decisive leadership in a tense moment.
Sits quietly and pensively in the carriage, reflecting on impending danger and the relentless pursuit by his enemies.
Accepts the letter from Gavroche and gives him a coin as a tip despite Gavroche's cheeky attitude.
Reads Marius's heartfelt letter to Cosette and shows deep distress and emotional pain at the thought of losing her.
Boldly opens the door and takes the letter from Gavroche despite the dangerous and tense context.
Calmly reads the heartfelt letter from Marius and processes the emotional weight, showing internal control.
Gives money to Gavroche promptly and reasonably, showing good judgment in social interaction.
Disguises himself in a dead soldier's jacket and uses the uniform to pass through enemy lines unchallenged.
Takes decisive action to find Marius despite inner turmoil and uncertainty.
Calmly convinces armed student sentries not to shoot and gains their trust to enter the barricade.
Spots snipers aiming at Enjolras, shoots to protect him and the group, preventing harm.
Refuses thanks from Enjolras and Marius, instead requests to take care of the spy Javert, showing a protective and responsible attitude.
Carries a knife and meets Javert with implied intent to harm, but instead uses the knife to cut Javert free.
Spots snipers aiming at Enjolras, quickly grabs a gun and shoots to disperse them, protecting his allies.
Calmly negotiates with Enjolras to entrust him with Javert, showing confidence and presence of mind in a tense situation.
Carries a knife and approaches Javert to cut him free, demonstrating careful planning and control in a dangerous moment.
Cuts Javert free from danger, ensuring his life is safe.
Tells Javert to leave without making any conditions or bargains, showing trust and forgiveness.
Points a gun at Javert but fires a shot into the air to encourage him to leave unharmed.
Cuts Javert free with a knife despite threat, shows decisiveness and control in a dangerous situation.
Calmly asserts his moral stance and commands Javert to leave without bargaining, demonstrating confidence and clear thinking.
Raises his gun, points it at Javert to assert authority, then fires a warning shot into the air, showing measured restraint and command over the situation.
Listens to Marius's heartfelt song and is visibly moved.
Paces anxiously, prays sincerely for Marius's safety, expressing fatherly concern and hope.
Moves quietly and attentively through the cafe, listens carefully to Marius's song, showing emotional awareness and attentiveness.
Paces, unable to sleep, showing anxious concern and restlessness but still maintains vigilance near the barricade.
Prays sincerely and thoughtfully for Marius, demonstrating emotional intelligence and care, but without immediate action associated.
Kneels next to the sleeping Marius, silently wishing him peace, joy, and life, expressing a deep desire for the boy to live and be safe even if he himself must die.
Moves among the fighters, tending to the wounded and lifting down the dead regardless of his own safety.
Carries Marius away from the barricade amid danger, confronts and incapacitates a soldier with one blow to protect Marius.
Carries an injured Marius through a dangerous escape route, identifies the iron grate as an exit, and uses the sewer system to evade soldiers.
Reaches an intersection in the sewer and assesses his fatigue before resting and placing Marius down cautiously.
Seizes Thenardier to stop him and finds the way out of the sewers, ensuring Marius's safety.
Holds Marius above his head while sinking in filth and continues moving forward despite danger to himself.
Upon waking, instantly seizes Thenardier and forces him to reveal the way out, demonstrating quick reaction and assertiveness.
Carries an unconscious Marius on his back through the dangerous and sinking sewers despite immense physical difficulty, showing physical endurance, determination, and resilience.
Follows the direction given by Thenardier, who intentionally misleads him, yet Valjean perseveres despite the deception, continuing to navigate without giving up.

Momentarily sinks beneath sewer water and nearly loses Marius, indicating the extreme challenge of the situation, but successfully resurfaces, reflecting controlled presence of mind under life-threatening conditions.
Rescues Marius from the sewers despite his own extreme physical exhaustion.
Insists to Javert that Marius has done no wrong and requires his family's care.
Faces Javert confidently, accepting the consequences of his actions without bitterness or hostility.
Keeps walking past Javert knowing Javert may shoot him, calmly willing to die instead of fighting or fleeing.
Chooses to let Javert go free despite having the opportunity for vengeance and justice.
Acts in a way that profoundly unsettles Javert and disrupts his rigid worldview, demonstrating moral and psychological insight.
Accepts Marius's gratitude warmly and calls him 'my son', indicating a sincere and affectionate acceptance.
Confesses his criminal past honestly to Marius despite the personal cost, showing trustworthiness and sincerity.
Prepares to leave Cosette's life to protect her reputation, prioritizing her well-being over his own comfort.
His confession causes Marius shock and disturbance, possibly creating emotional tension.
Tells Marius to tell Cosette he has gone on a journey and to hide the truth about his departure to protect her feelings.
Leaves quietly without saying goodbye to Cosette despite her love and need for him on her wedding day.
Calmly instructs Marius on how to handle Cosette’s emotions by asking him to promise not to reveal the truth and to say that he has gone on a long journey.
Leaves quietly and without farewell, showing control and acceptance of the necessity of his departure despite personal sacrifice.
Sits quietly in the cab, eyes closed, possibly reflecting or weary, showing no sign of panic or rash behavior.
Prays calmly and with acceptance in the face of death, showing emotional resilience and spiritual readiness.
Expresses gratitude and warmth on seeing Cosette and Marius, showing emotional intelligence and the ability to maintain meaningful relationships even in his final moments.
Does not engage in any action to improve or change his situation, accepts dying passively.
Carries wounded Marius from the barricade and brings him home safely to Cosette.
Writes a last confession expressing transformation from hatred to love and entrusts it to Cosette.
Expresses readiness to meet Fantine in the afterlife, showing forgiveness and seeking mercy.
